thread.title: So, you don't like the Jays? Here’s where you can duck out if you’re near the game
thread.title_full: So, you don't like the Jays? Here’s where you can duck out if you’re near the game | Toronto Star

author: Peter Edwards
title: So, you don't like the Jays? Here’s where you can duck out if you’re near the game
text:
So the Blue Jays playoff hubbub rubs you the wrong way?
You’re a heretic who believes there is more to existence than curves, sliders and swatting a little ball with a stick?
Here are five places to feel alive within a long fly ball of the Rogers Centre.
Steam Whistle Brewery
There’s a popular story that Steam Whistle Brewery was almost named “Three Fired Guys Brewing Company” because its founders made unplanned exits from Upper Canada Brewing Company years ago.
Perhaps it’s true, which would explain the “3FG” on the bottom of the craft brewery’s distinctive green bottles.
Today, the brewery in the historic roundhouse by the rail tracks on Bremner Blvd. is a place when you can be alternately educated and mildly lubricated on one of its many tours.
Ripley’s Aquarium of Canada
Where else can you take a selfie with a shark? (No boss or divorce lawyer jokes needed)
The Aquarium of Canada next to the CN Tower and Rogers Centre has what’s billed as “North America’s longest underwater viewing tunnel.”
Stroll surrounded by more than 5.7 million litres of water and get as close as anyone should to horseshoe crabs and rays.
CN Tower
You don’t need directions to this landmark .
Just look up – 356m (1,136’) up.
You can get to the top in 58 seconds.
Once there, you have a choice of dining, taking photos, or dangling from a rope on EdgeWalk.
Leon’s furniture store
Looking for a sleeper set or a La-Z-Boy?
Don’t want the type that you find patrolling the Leafs’ defense line?
There’s always Leon’s , the priced-to-sell furniture store in the old rail roundhouse, above retired rail tracks.
If you can stay awake on a Lazy Boy, the sightlines of the city are spectacular.
The Royal Alexandra Theatre
This King St. W. building is a National Historic Landmark buildin g that’s now home to Kinky Boots, with music and lyrics from pop star Cyndi Lauper.
The Star’s Richard Ouzounian clearly found it to his liking, calling it a “spectacular celebration of song, dance and comedy.”
